channel.title: Comments on: Better life index – a post mortem

item.title: By: malaika
item.dc:creator: malaika
item.description:
"Even if we had equivalent talent inhouse, it would still had been more effective to outsource it."
this is really key, and what keeps so many organisations already established in their field and well-regarded for their expertise from recognising the critical need for data visualisation, and more visual/smart/creative data manifestation in general. companies seem to think, they need to hire a designer to have great design, and if they don't want to budget for a great designer, there's no other way. we need a web tool connecting freelance designers and orgs that have a need for this work, so both profit in an economic and visually exciting manner.

item.title: By: Enrico Bertini
item.dc:creator: Enrico Bertini
item.description: Jerome, thanks a lot for sharing this story with us. There is a desperate need for showing what happens behind the curtains of data visualization projects. item.title: By: Greg, OOM Creative
item.dc:creator: Greg, OOM Creative
item.description: Thank you for reporting insight about the project development. It's really interesting the divide in data visualization between audience and knowing experts, and how design needs to bridge across both domains. This is sometimes difficult to achieve when there are so many parties involved in the process. I think the lessons you've outlined are great building blocks for how organizations should approach designed data viz strategies that offer higher ROI than ones based on generic graphing or audience bamboozlement.
